Scheme 1 Plausible description of p-cymene primary and secondary oxidation product formation route. (1) p-Cymene, (2) primary cymene hydroperoxide, (3) tertiary cymene hydroperoxide (TCHP), (4) 4-methyl acetophenone (4-MAP), (5) 1-methyl-4-(1-methylvinyl) benzene (MMVB), (6) 4-isopropyl benzaldehyde (4-IPBA), (7) 4-isopropyl benzyl alcohol (4-IPBAL), and (8) 4-isopropyl benzoic acid (4-IPBAC). Fig. 1 Comparison of Ru supported catalysts catalytic activities in p-cymene oxidation. Reaction conditions: p-cymene (114mmol), TBHP initiator (6mmol), catalyst (0.1g), O2 flow (30ml/min), T =90°C, t =4h. Fig. 2 Effect of 3%Ru/CNF catalyst on chain initiation rates for CH activation. Reaction conditions: p-cymene (114mmol), catalyst (0.10g), TBHP initiator (6mmol), T =90°C, t =3h. Fig. 3 Effect of 3%Ru/CNF catalyst amount on p-cymene oxidation rates. Reaction conditions: p-cymene (114mmol), TBHP initiator (6mmol), O2 flow (30ml/min), T =90°C, t =4h. Fig. 4 Time-dependence of conversion rates and products distribution. Reaction conditions: p-cymene (114mmol), TBHP initiator (6mmol), 3%Ru/CNF catalyst (0.15g), O2 flow (30ml/min), T =90°C, t =5h. Makgwane a b ⁎ Suprakas Sinha Ray a b ⁎ a Department of Applied Chemistry, University of Johannesburg, Doornfontein, 2028, South Africa b DST/CSIR National Centre for Nanostructured Materials, Council for Scientific and Industrial Research, Pretoria 0001, South Africa ⁎ Corresponding authors at: DST/CSIR National Centre for Nanostructured Materials, Council for Scientific and Industrial Research, Pretoria 0001, South Africa. Graphical abstract Highlights ► Carbon nanofiber (CNF) dispersed Ru is active for aerobic oxidation of p-cymene. ► Ru/CNF activity is influenced by metal loadings, reducibility and reaction conditions. ► Enhanced Ru activity is not nanoparticle size dependent. ► Ru/CNF is structurally stable and re-usable for several cycles without loss of activity. Highly dispersed, nanosized ruthenium (Ru) particles anchored on carbon nanofibers (CNFs) with varying Ru loadings (1–7wt.%) showed effective catalytic activity in the aerobic oxidation of p-cymene using molecular oxygen. The activity of the Ru catalysts was influenced by the structural properties that resulted from the different metal loadings and by various reaction variables, such as the temperature, the amount of catalyst and the type of radical–initiator substrate. Under optimized reaction conditions, the 3%Ru/CNF catalyst exhibited excellent performance with a selectivity of 42% toward primary cymene hydroperoxide (PCHP) and 33% toward tertiary cymene hydroperoxide (TCHP) at 55% p-cymene conversion achieved within 5h at 90°C. The results demonstrated that the direct participation of the catalyst in p-cymene CH bond activation occurred via catalytic decomposition of tertiary-butyl hydroperoxide (TBHP), which was added as an initiator, into a free-radical chain initiator rather than the direct H-atom abstraction by the catalyst itself. The catalytic efficacy displayed by the Ru/CNF catalysts provides encouraging results for the activation of CH bonds of liquid-phase alkyl aromatic hydrocarbons, such as p-cymene, toward the introduction of an oxygen atom. The catalyst was reusable for five consecutive reaction cycles without appreciable loss of activity. Moreover, Ru/CNF catalyst was active for extended substrate scope application in the oxidation of other alkyl-substituted aromatics. Keywords Ruthenium Nanocatalyst Liquid phase oxidation p-Cymene Tertiary cymene hydroperoxide Primary cymene hydroperoxide 1 Introduction Liquid-phase oxidations of alkyl aromatic hydrocarbons are important reactions for the synthesis of highly valuable intermediates in the fine and specialty chemical industry [1]. The problems with reactions are their slow kinetics and low conversion rates and the occurrence of non-selective processes that lead to the formation of large amounts of by-products, which complicates the product workup [2]. An example is the liquid-phase oxidation of p-cymene (4-isopropyltoluene) to two predominant intermediate products: tertiary cymene hydroperoxide (TCHP) and primary cymene hydroperoxide (PCHP) [3,4]. Other secondary oxidation products that result from this reaction include 4-methyl acetophenone, 4-isopropyl benzyl alcohol, 4-isopropyl benzaldehyde and 4-isopropyl benzoic acid, which are the building-block molecules of other value-added chemicals. For example, 4-methyl acetophenone is valuable in the perfume industry, whereas 4-isopropyl benzaldehyde is mainly used as a flavoring agent in the food industry [4]. The TCHP produced in the p-cymene oxidation process is catalytically decomposed into p-cresol and acetone [4,5]. Naturally, cresols are isolated from tar in the coal-to-liquid (CTL) process as a mixture of phenolic, cresols and xylenols [6]. The industrial non-catalyzed oxidation of p-cymene in the liquid phase is masked by low conversion rates (15–20%) and by slow reaction rates with long reaction times of 12–14h [3]. The development of a p-cymene oxidation process based on a heterogeneous solid catalyst in the liquid phase remains the ultimate goal for green catalytic chemistry. Over the last few years, several catalyst systems have been explored for their catalytic activity toward p-cymene oxidation [6–11]. The general finding was that the oxidation products of p-cymene depended on the nature of the metal catalyst and the reaction conditions used. For example, in the liquid phase, hydroperoxides are isolated in high yields, whereas, in the gas phase, oxidation results in a different product spectrum that constitutes mainly carbonyls [9,11]. A desirable catalyst should therefore be able to improve both the conversion rates and the selectivity in such reactions. In addition, the catalyst should exhibit resistance to rapid deactivations induced by the harsh conditions of the liquid-phase reaction medium or by oxygen poisoning. Ruthenium (Ru) is an important catalytically active noble metal that has been applied extensively in various reactions, including hydrogenations [12,13], oxidations [14,15], oxidative esterification [16], CC coupling reactions [17], and Fischer–Tropsch synthesis as a metal promoter [18]. Liquid-phase oxidation reactions with Ru metal have been performed with Ru used as a homogeneous metal complex anchored onto different ligands [19]. In cases where Ru has been used as a heterogeneous solid catalyst in oxidation reactions, excellent catalytic activity has been reported for low-temperature carbon monoxide oxidation as well as methanol and ammonia oxidations [20]. The oxidation of HCl (Deacon process) for the production of chlorine is another example of a well-studied catalytic process over a model solid heterogeneous catalyst, RuO2 (110) [21–23]. The intriguing catalytic properties of Ru make it an interesting catalyst to study; especially with respect to the activation of CH bonds in aromatic hydrocarbons to form oxygenate derivatives. The usual approach to improve the catalytic properties of active metals is either to support the metal on a material with high surface area or/and promote the reaction with a second metal to modify the electronic and structural properties of the active metal and, thus, its activity or selectivity. Furthermore, the synthesis of active-metal catalysts with nanoscale particle sizes supported on suitable supports enhances their catalytic properties that are inaccessible in their bulk form [24]. As a result, the structural properties of the support surface are of primary importance in the design of nanocatalyst materials [25]. The activities of Ru catalysts on different supports, such as SiO2 [26], Al2O3 [27], TiO2 [28], MgO [29], CeO2 [30], and CNT [31], have been investigated for several reactions. The support plays an important role in heterogeneous solid catalysis: (1) to disperse and give a high surface area of the active phase, and (2) to stabilize and facilitate the mass or heat transfer in a diffusion-limited reaction. For oxidation reactions, the surface oxygen atoms and oxygen vacancies of the support can significantly enhance the catalyst performance due to the high mobility of reactive oxygen species [31–33]. To the best of our knowledge, the literature contains no reports of the catalytic activity of a nanosized Ru/CNF (carbon nanofiber) supported catalyst in the liquid-phase oxidation of hydrocarbons. The CNF support provides structural properties that favor catalysis, such as a high surface area, high mechanical strength, the presence of inert carbon and a chemically tunable structure amenable to the high dispersion of active-metal nanoparticles [34,35]. The surface oxygen groups of the functionalized CNF structure can aid in the creation of unique metal–support interactions with enhanced catalytically active sites. This paper reports on the catalytic activity and the nature of various loadings of nanosized Ru supported on CNF in the oxidation of p-cymene using molecular oxygen (O2) as the oxidant. The results demonstrated excellent activity of the Ru catalyst in activating the p-cymene CH bond for functionalization into oxygenates. A combination of different techniques, including high resolution transmission electron microscope (HRTEM), X-ray diffraction (XRD), inductively coupled plasma (ICP), nitrogen (N2) physisorption and hydrogen temperature-programed reduction (H2-TPR), were used to gain insight into the nature of the dispersed nanosized Ru catalyst particles to allow us to rationalize the obtained catalytic results. Our results with respect to p-cymene oxidation provide the basis for the development of an efficient catalytic route for the production of oxygenates from hydrocarbons using Ru-based heterogeneous catalysts under mild reaction conditions. To further demonstrate on the versatility of the Ru/CNF catalyst system activity, we extended its substrate scope application to the oxidation of cumene and styrene. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The supported Ru catalysts with different metal loadings were prepared with CNF supports (Alfa-Aesar, Ward Hill, USA; specific surface area∼220m2/g) and ruthenium trichloride hydrate (RuCl3·xH2O, Aldrich Chemicals, 99.98%). The Ru nanoparticles were prepared prior to their deposition onto the CNFs. For the preparation of the Ru nanoparticles, polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) (Aldrich Chemicals, weight average molecular weight∼10,000, 80% hydrolyzed) was used as a protecting agent. In a typical preparation method, 2ml of aqueous PVA (2wt.%) was added to 300ml of deionized H2O, and the amount of Ru was adjusted based on the total w/w% of CNFs to be added. The resulting Ru sol–gel was stirred vigorously at 70°C for 15min, followed by the injection of a few drops (∼2ml) of an aqueous solution of 1.0M NaBH4 (Aldrich, 97% purity). The mixture was allowed to age for 6h at room temperature. After 6h, the CNF support was added, and the mixture was stirred overnight. Different Ru loadings were prepared with the nominal amount of Ru varied in the range of 1–7wt.%. The solids were collected by filtration, washed thoroughly with distilled water and dried at 110°C for 12h. They were subsequently activated by being heated at a rate of 10°C/min from 25 to 350°C in a stream of flowing air; the samples were held at 350°C for 3h, and the gas was switched to H2 for 2h. The prepared catalysts were denoted as 1%Ru/CNF, 3%Ru/CNF, 5%Ru/CNF and 7%Ru/CNF based on the nominal Ru loadings of 1, 3, 5, and 7wt.%, respectively, relative to the CNF support. 2.2 Catalytic oxidation procedure The catalytic activity testing of different Ru-based catalysts was performed in a 50ml two-necked round-bottom flask equipped with the magnetic stirrer and a reflux condenser; the tests were conducted under atmospheric pressure conditions to avoid explosive conditions that may be induced with the use pure oxygen. The p-cymene (114mmol), the 70% TBHP radical initiator substrate (6mmol) and the catalyst (0.10g) were added to the reactor. The temperature of the reactor was controlled by immersing it in a heated oil bath. O2 was introduced by continuous bubbling using a glass pipette with a frit at the bottom of the reactor dipped into the reaction mixture. All of the reactions were performed with an O2 flow rate of 30ml/min. Samples withdrawn from the reactor that contained the p-cymene oxidation products were analyzed by gas chromatography (GC) using a Supelco SPB-20 column (30m×0.25mm i.d.×0.25mm) on an Agilent 7890A gas chromatograph equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID). The GC analysis program was as follows: FID temperature (300°C), injector temperature (200°C), and oven column temperature, 50°C (3min), then ramped to 200°C at 10°C/min. Products were identified by comparing their retention times to those of authentic samples. The (nitrobenzene) was used as internal standard with methanol as analysis solvent for GC quantitative analysis of the different oxidation products. The hydroperoxide formed as a reaction intermediate in the liquid-phase oxidation of aromatics cannot be directly detected by GC analysis because they thermally decompose into carbonyls. To analyze the content of the oxidation products that contained the hydroperoxides, the reaction liquid solution was treated with triphenylphosphine to reduce the hydroperoxides into their corresponding quantifiable alcohols. The TCHP content analyzed directly without triphenylphosphine treatment and after reducing to alcohol with triphenylphosphine gave similar results indicating that the formed TCHP during the oxidation reaction was not converted into corresponding alcohol but rather to methyl acetophenone as discussed later. To study the possible leaching of the metal catalysts, we used the following reaction conditions: catalyst=0.1g, temperature=90°C and time=1h. After the 1h reaction time, the catalyst was separated by filtration while the liquid reaction mixture was hot. For catalyst recyclability experiments, after each reaction cycle, the catalyst was filtered from the liquid solution, washed with acetone and dried in air for 2h at 110°C before it was used in the next cycle. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Activity testing of different Ru-based catalysts The catalytic effect of different supported Ru/CNF catalysts were evaluated in the liquid-phase oxidation of p-cymene using O2 as the terminal oxidant. Initially, the blank control reaction in the absence of the catalyst was performed to establish the baseline performance of the non-catalyzed reaction. The non-catalytic oxidation of p-cymene showed a low conversion of approximately 2% due to the long induction period needed to initiate the free-radical chain autoxidation mechanism via CH bond activation presented in Fig. 1 . All of the evaluated catalysts showed a substantial catalytic effect with typical conversions greater than 15% achieved within 4h reaction time. For comparison, the conversion was 2% for the non-catalyzed reaction. The induction period for the catalyzed reactions was reduced to approximately less than 10min. For example, approximately 5% conversions were obtained with all of the tested catalysts within 30min, whereas the non-catalyzed reaction required 4h to achieve approximately 2% conversion. Among the supported Ru/CNF catalysts, 3%Ru/CNF exhibited high catalytic performance with a conversion of 35%, whereas the catalyst with the lowest metal loading, 1%Ru/CNF, afforded a low conversion of 18% under similar reaction conditions. Overall, the effect of the metal loading on the activity of the Ru–CNF catalysts followed the increasing conversion order of 3%Ru/CNF>5%Ru/CNF>7%Ru/CNF>1%Ru/CNF (Fig. 1 and Table 1 ). The product selectivity varied in proportion to the increase in the Ru metal loading and the p-cymene conversion amount (Table 1). The CNF support also showed a small catalytic effect, with a conversion of approximately 4%. That a nanostructured material showed a catalytic effect as a metal-free catalyst to activate hydrocarbon CH bonds is not surprising because such observations have been reported previously for functionalized bare carbon nanotubes (CNTs) [36]. The main oxidation products detected after 4h were TCHP; its over-oxidation-derived product, 4-methyl acetophenone; PCHP; and its by-products, 4-isopropylbenzoic acid (4-IPBA) and 4-isopropyl benzaldehyde (4-IPB) for all of the evaluated Ru/CNF catalysts. In order to comprehend the catalytic effect of the Ru metal catalyst, we performed the control experiment using the commercial RuO2 (IV) powder catalyst under similar reaction conditions used for the Ru/CNF supported catalysts. The RuO2 also showed effective catalytic activity toward the p-cymene conversion into different oxygen-containing aromatic products. It is noteworthy to mention that the unsupported RuO2 was free of chloride ions, which eliminated any possible misinterpretation of the supported Ru/CNF catalysts activity that might have been due to possible presence of soluble chloride ions from the RuCl3 metal precursor salt used to prepare the Ru/CNF catalysts that can exert some substantial catalytic effect. The RuO2 exhibited low catalytic activity when compared to all supported Ru catalysts except for 1%Ru/CNF loading catalyst which showed closely similar activity (Table 1). As a result, it can therefore be concluded that the CNF support had an effect on improving the catalytic activity of the Ru nanoparticles catalyst. On the issue of selectivity, the pure RuO2 exhibited similar trend obtained with carbon nanofibers dispersed Ru nanoparticle catalysts except that it exhibited the formation of high amount of other by-products apart from the known or identified ones. This suggests the insight into further Ru catalyst selectivity improvement that can be improved by the use of other possible supports or promoter metals to suppress the formation of non-selective Ru active sites. 3.2 Influence of Ru on the chain initiation rates of CH activation One interesting issue that requires further elaboration is how the Ru catalyst participated in the p-cymene liquid-phase oxidation during CH activation. In general, the catalyst can actively participate in the reaction chain initiation either by (1) the decomposition of an added ROOH radical initiator (e.g., TBHP) or (2) the direct activation of the CH bond followed by abstraction of an H atom to form p-cymene free radicals. To investigate this issue, we studied the influence of the catalyst on the reaction initiation rates by performing several sets of experiments. First, we oxidized p-cymene in the presence of the 3%Ru/CNF catalyst with TBHP added as an initiator, and the catalyst was removed from the reaction mixture by hot-filtration after 1h; the filtrate was subsequently allowed to react further for 2h. Second, the p-cymene oxidation with only TBHP added was initially performed in the absence of a catalyst for 1h; the catalyst was subsequently added, and the reaction was allowed to proceed for 2h. Third, the oxidation was performed in the presence of p-cymene and catalyst without added TBHP for 3h. In addition, we performed the normal oxidation reaction of p-cymene for 3h in the presence of a catalyst and TBHP as an initiator. The results obtained for this set of experiments are illustrated in Fig. 2 . The oxidation initiation rates when only TBHP and p-cymene were used in the absence of the catalyst were relatively slow. This result confirms the hypothesis of Hermans et al. [37–39] that chain initiation during hydrocarbon oxidation by self-thermal homolytic decomposition of hydroperoxide (i.e., ROOH into free-radicals=RO, OH, R) is inadequate to significantly facilitate autoxidation-driven reaction chain initiation rates. This hypothesis was further demonstrated when the catalyst was removed from the reaction after 1h. At 1h after the catalyst was removed, the conversion was approximately 11.4%, which indicated that the autocatalytic oxidation mechanism (initiation/propagation/termination) was already initiated. However, with a further increase of the reaction time to up to 3h for the filtrate reaction mixture without the catalyst, the reaction rate was slow and resulted in an increase in the conversion of less than 3%, from 11.4% to 14.4%. Furthermore, in the second experiment, when the reaction was initially performed in the absence of catalyst (i.e., p-cymene and TBHP only), no conversion was achieved after 1h. However, with the addition of the catalyst after 1h, the p-cymene conversion increased immediately, which indicated the active participation of the catalyst in initiating the reaction, which consequently improved the oxidation rate (Fig. 2). Finally, when the oxidation was performed in the absence of the TBHP initiator, the activation of the p-cymene CH bonds by Ru itself also proved to be slow. As a result, the activation of both O2 and CH simultaneously in the absence of a hydroperoxide initiator was inadequate. A comparison of the different results with respect to the reaction chain-initiation rates with the normal oxidation in the presence of both the catalyst and the TBHP initiator demonstrated the active participation of the catalyst in CH bond activation. The chain-initiation by self-thermal homolytic decomposition of added TBHP (i.e., ROOH) as the radical initiator is explained by Eqs. (1) and (2): (1) ROOH→RO + OH (2) RH+ OH→R +H2O In contrast, chain-reaction initiation by catalytic decomposition of the added radical initiator substrate that involves the active redox properties of the metal catalyst is explained by the general equations (3) and (4): (3) Oxidation:ROOH+M(n+) →ROO−Mn(n+1) +H+ (4) Reduction:ROOH+M(n+1) →ROO +M(n+) +H+ The overall net reaction of Eqs. (3) and (4) that describe the decomposition of the hydroperoxide into alkoxy and alkylperoxy radicals is represented by Eq. (5): (5) 2 ROOH ⟶ M ( n + 1 ) / M n + RO + RO + H + (6) ROO +RH→R +ROOH The rates of reactions (3) and (4) depend on the metal redox potential, which is usually separated by one or two oxidation states. These oxidation states enable both reactions to occur concurrently on the metal surface. The formed peroxy radicals (ROO) in Eqs. (3) and (4) are able to abstract H atoms of p-cymene (RH) to form another R radical and stable cymene hydroperoxide (ROOH). The contribution of TBHP (ROOH) as radical initiator can be assumed to play an important role in the initial stage of the reaction, most likely within 30min of the start of the reaction. After the chain autocatalytic mechanism is initiated, the source of the ROO, RO, OH and R radicals is the formed cymene hydroperoxide, which propagates the chain length and is, in turn, terminated via Eq. (6) to form stable primary and tertiary cymene hydroperoxides. Based on the previous explanations and the obtained results, we propose that the participation of the Ru/CNF catalysts in the oxidation of p-cymene was mainly via the catalytic decomposition of ROOH (TBHP initiator) into reactive radical species that are responsible for reaction chain initiation rather than the direct H-atom abstraction by the catalyst itself or the direct activation of gaseous O2. In this case, the Ru catalyst reacts with TBHP to form a coordinate metal–alkoxy radical complex with the Ru catalyst being reduced and re-oxidized by gaseous molecular oxygen [2]. Although this mechanism explains how the Ru catalyst participated in the activation of the p-cymene CH bond, our results did not reveal the resulting oxidation state change of Ru during this early reaction stage of p-cymene activation. Consequently, the observed better catalytic performance of the Ru catalyst in CH activation is attributed to its good interchangeable reducibility and oxidizability, which is an important feature in the oxidation reaction mechanism with respect to the enhancement of the chain-initiation rates, as illustrated in Eqs. (3)–(5). Further studies are underway trying to comprehend the actual role of the different Ru metal oxidation states on catalyst activity and selectivity performance. 3.3 Influence of reaction parameters on oxidation rates The results in Table 2 reveal the effect of temperature on the oxidation rates and the product selectivity. The conversion was shown to depend on the reaction temperature, increasing from 23.4% at 80°C to 42% at 110°C. However, the selectivity toward TCHP and PCHP were affected by the increased reaction temperature in that the amount of over-oxidation products accumulated increased significantly. As a result, a reaction temperature of 90°C was chosen for further investigations of the effects of other reaction parameters. Table 3 shows the effect of different initiator substrates on the p-cymene oxidation initiation rate in the presence of O2 as an oxidant. The TBHP resulted in the highest oxidation rates, thus higher p-cymene conversion rates, compared to those achieved with the other initiators. The use of H2O2 as a radical initiator resulted in only 10.7% conversion after 4h. The poor chain-initiation rates achieved with H2O2 as the initiator compared to those achieved with TBHP and CHP oil can be attributed to its rapid decomposition, which depends on the nature of the catalyst. As radical initiators, the TBHP and CHP oil gave relatively similar selectivity trends toward the formation of major oxidation products, TCHP and PCHP, although their p-cymene conversion rates were significantly different. The results showed that the effect of the type of initiator substrate on the oxidation rates was an important factor with respect to the observed Ru catalytic effect. Moreover, the effect of the initiator on the conversion rates was more pronounced than its effect on selectivity. The use of CHP oil as an initiator for p-cymene is advantageous because the introduction of undesired by-products, such as tert-butanol, from the use of TBHP can be avoided. However, in the present study, only trace amounts of tert-butanol was observed at p-cymene conversions of 30% or greater, which indicated that all of the added TBHP was completely converted into hydroperoxy free radicals during the early chain-initiation stage. The effect of the amount of 3%Ru/CNF catalyst on the p-cymene oxidation rates and on the product selectivity was studied in the range of 0.05–0.25g (Fig. 3 ). The conversion of p-cymene varied linearly with increasing amounts of catalyst from 0.025g up to 0.15g and then started to level off at 0.25g. The selectivity toward PCHP and TCHP formation was also significantly affected by the increase in the amount of catalyst (Fig. 3). The effect of using a large amount of catalyst was evident by the increased amount of 4-MAP, which significantly reduced the TCHP selectivity for catalyst amounts greater than 0.15g. As a result, 0.1–0.15g of catalyst appeared to be the optimum loading to give acceptable conversion rates with selectivity of greater than 70% and with both TCHP and PCHP preserved. Fig. 4 illustrates the time dependence of the p-cymene conversion rates and the evolution of the oxidation products for 5h of reaction time. The conversion increased gradually with increasing reaction time up to 4h and started to plateau thereafter to give a maximum of 55% conversion after 5h. At low conversions of less than 12%, the most predominant component was PCHP, with a selectivity as high as 82%, followed by TCHP with 10% selectivity. In the oxidation of p-cymene, both the methyl group (CH3) at the 1-position and the isopropyl group {CH(CH3)2} at the 4-position of the benzene ring almost certainly undergo oxidation or H-atom abstraction, as shown in Scheme 1 . The rates of H-atom abstraction in the CH bonds of both groups have been reported to be 1:4 (methyl:isopropyl) [3]. Interestingly, in the present study, the Ru/CNF catalysts favored a high oxidation rate at the methyl group compared to CH bond activation of the isopropyl group, which indicates a possible sensitivity to the catalyst structure and substrate. The over-oxidation of PCHP resulted in the formation of 4-isopropyl benzyl alcohol, 4-ispropyl benzaldehyde and 4-isopropyl benzoic acid as secondary products (Scheme 1). However, the initially formed TCHP subsequently underwent decomposition to form 4-methyl acetophenone, and the amount of 4-methyl acetophenone increased gradually but significantly with increased reaction time (Fig. 4 and Scheme 1). The decrease in the TCHP selectivity can be rationalized in two ways: (1) by the increasing gradual accumulation of the by-products formed from the thermal decomposition of TCHP, or (2) by the catalytic TCHP decomposition effect. In the first case, the decomposition of hydroperoxide is temperature sensitive, and, in the second case, the rate of TCHP decomposition can be slightly influenced by the active-metal catalyst [40]. At 55% conversion after 5h, the 3%Ru-CNF catalyst gave a selectivity of 42% PCHP and 33% TCHP. A noticeable slight change in product distribution with gradual increase of TCHP formation was observed indicating a possible change on catalyst surface active selective sites for TCHP. We performed recyclability experiments to examine the stability of the catalytic performance of Ru metal under p-cymene oxidation reaction conditions in a prolonged usage period. After each reaction cycle, the catalyst was separated from the liquid product by filtration, washed with acetone and dried in an oven under flowing air for 2h at 110°C before being used in the next reaction run. The catalyst showed a stable p-cymene conversion rate of approximately 36% for five consecutive reaction cycles (Fig. 5 ). These results confirmed that the 3%Ru/CNF catalyst could be used repeatedly without loss of activity. However, the selectivity toward PCHP changed with the number of times the catalyst was re-used (Table 4 ). This result indicated a possible change of the catalyst active sites that controlled the product selectivity. For example, we observed a PCHP selectivity of approximately 55% during the first re-use cycle, which decreased to approximately 38%. This decrease was attributed to the possible absorption of polar molecules onto the catalyst surface. Such absorption can affect the surface Ru species (i.e., the Ru oxidation states) and thus influence the oxidation selectivity sites upon prolonged catalyst usage, as will be discussed later. For the metal leaching tests, the catalyst and the reaction mixture were separated by filtration at the reaction temperature after 1h of reaction time. The obtained filtrate solution was allowed to react further for 2h for a total reaction time of 3h. After 1h of reaction and before removal of the catalyst, the substrate conversion was approximately 11%, and this conversion increased to only 13%. Under normal oxidation conditions (i.e., in the presence of a catalyst), the conversion was approximately 35% under the same reaction conditions used for the leaching experiments. The low conversion after the catalyst was removed during the leaching tests and the higher conversion under normal oxidation conditions indicated that no significant Ru leaching occurred or that any possible leaching that occurred did not influence the substrate conversion rates. 3.4 Catalyst substrate scope extension to other alkyl aromatics In order to probe the scope application of the nano-dispersed Ru/CNF catalyst system, we extended the study to other substituted aromatic compounds by performing oxidation of cumene and styrene as probe compounds. The styrene oxidation is an important reaction route for the synthesis of benzyl alcohol, benzaldehyde and benzoic acid, while cumene oxidation leads to the formation of cumene hydroperoxide and acetophenone (Table 5 ). It can be seen in Table 5 that the nanosized Ru dispersed on carbon nanofibers exhibited the catalytic effect in all tested liquid-phase oxidation reactions giving substantial substrate conversions. 3.5 Characterization of Ru-based catalysts Fig. 6 illustrates the XRD patterns of the nanosized Ru/CNF supported catalysts measured at ambient temperature. Low-intensity diffraction peaks attributable to the ruthenium catalyst were visible at 2θ =35°, 42° and 77° in some of the loaded Ru catalysts (Fig. 6). These peaks correspond to the (111), (200), and (311) Ru index plane lines, respectively. The diffraction peak that appeared at approximately 2θ =35° corresponds to ruthenium dioxide (RuO2), which originates from the exposure of the Ru sample to air during calcination or activation. Although the peaks that distinguish the formation of the metallic Ru phase from RuO2 or RuO were not clearly visible in the expected region of 2θ =43.9°, 47.3° and 50.2°, a low-intensity peak at approximately 2θ =48° was observed, which indicates the possible formation of metallic Ru. The XRD peaks at 2θ =42.2° and 44°, which overlap with the peaks of the pure CNF supports, have been previously attributed to be a hexagonal Ru phase [41]. The peaks at 2θ =26°, 32°, 52° and 74°, which correspond to index plane lines of (002), (100), (101) and (004), are attributed to highly graphitized characteristics of the CNF crystal structure (JCPDS; 41-0254). The low-intensity XRD peaks attributed to Ru correspond well with the TEM results and indicate the formation of Ru particles with an average diameter of 2–5nm. For 5wt.% and 7wt.% loadings, Ru metal particles larger than 4nm were observed, which were most likely formed by the agglomeration or clustering of particles. Fig. 7 presents the H2-TPR profiles of Ru metal nanoparticles dispersed on CNF supports with various metal loadings. The reduction peaks in the TPR curves of all of the Ru-based catalysts showed slightly different patterns categorized by three different and distinctive reduction temperatures in a range of 50–250°C, 250–450°C or 450–800°C. The pattern of pure CNF showed (Fig. 7a) two reduction peaks that appeared at different temperatures in the ranges of 300–500°C and 550–750°C. The reduction peak that appeared at 100–200°C in the patterns of all of the supported Ru-based catalysts is due to the reduction of Ru(3+) to Ru(0) that occurred either during the catalyst preparation or during the calcination [42,43]. As evident in Fig. 7a–e, the intensity of the peak in the reduction temperature range of 100–200°C was found to increase significantly with increasing Ru metal loadings in the CNF support. In addition to the Ru reduction peak at 100–200°C, the 1%Ru/CNF catalyst showed an additional broad reduction peak that stretched from 300 to 550°C, and this reduction temperature was different than those of the catalysts with high Ru loadings Ru in the same TPR reduction temperature region. The broad peak at approximately 600–780°C in the profiles of all of the supported Ru catalysts and in that of pure CNF support (Fig. 7a–e) is assigned solely to the carbon in the CNF support [32]. The presence of the reduction peak in the profiles of all of the Ru catalysts at temperatures greater than 450°C indicates the possible formation of strong interactions between the Ru metal and the support, which was evident from the TEM images, as discussed later. According to the TPR results, the 3%Ru/CNF catalyst possibly exhibited a stronger metal–support interaction than did the other catalysts with respect to the intensities of the peaks in the reduction temperature range of 300–500°C. Near the 300–500°C range, the profile of the 1%Ru/CNF catalyst showed three distinctive reduction peaks at 200°C, 300–400°C and 400–500°C. These differences can significantly affect the catalytic performance of the different catalysts, as observed in Table 1. Moreover, with respect to the reduction of Ru at 100–200°C, the peaks recorded for the different Ru supported catalysts showed a slight shift in the reduction temperature with the 3%Ru/CNF catalyst, which indicates a slightly lower reduction temperature than those observed for the other catalysts. As expected, the intensity of the reduction peaks was higher for catalysts with higher Ru contents. These differences in the reduction patterns of the Ru-based catalysts suggest the presence of a mixture of Ru species that interact differently with the support and with various degrees of Ru reducibility, which is affected by the metal loadings in the CNF supports. Table 6 lists the BET surface areas, the micropore volumes from the N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms, the ICP elemental analysis results and the mean particles size estimated from TEM images. The amount of Ru deposited onto the CNF supports was measured by ICP. The results indicated a slightly lower amount of Ru (for loading 1–5wt.%) than was expected based on the nominal loading, which was most likely because some of the Ru species might have been washed away after the deposition–washing procedure. For all of the supported catalysts, a small decrease in the specific BET surface areas and pore volumes of CNF was observed after the Ru nanoparticles were deposited, which decreased with increasing Ru metal loading. Such an observation is obvious because CNF surface is covered with Ru nanoparticles. Figs. 8 and 9 show the TEM morphology images of the supported Ru/CNF catalysts and their respective particles size distribution graphs. As evident from Fig. 9a–d, all of the Ru supported catalysts showed the formation of nanoparticles with various dispersion patterns and with mean particle sizes in the 2.3–5nm range. The TEM images of the catalysts showed well-dispersed Ru nanoparticles on CNF nano-structured supports for all of the different metal loadings. The Ru nanoparticles were lying on the outside surface wall of the nanofibers, and some of the particles indicated the formation of strong interactions between the Ru and the support, as illustrated for the 3%Ru/CNF catalyst (Fig. 3e–g). The possible formation of strong Ru–support interactions was also observed in the H2-TPR results (Fig. 7). We propose that the carboxylate groups introduced onto the CNF support make the formation of RuOCNF interactions possible during the immobilization of the Ru catalyst. The observed RuOCNF bond formation may also occur under the influence of oxidation conditions when air is used during the calcination step, which may lead to the self-dispersion of Ru oxidation into ruthenium oxide on CNF. For high Ru metal loadings of 7wt.%, TEM images indicated the possible formation of Ru particle aggregates, and these aggregates may have influenced the TPR results compared to the results of other metal loadings, which may have consequently led to the different catalytic performance results (Table 1). With respect to the observed catalytic performance of the Ru catalysts in the selective oxidation of p-cymene, based on the particle sizes determined from the TEM images, the metal loadings significantly affected the catalyst structure and thus its catalytic performance. Moreover, the H2-TPR results indicated different reducibility patterns; thus, the active metal catalyst dispersion might have contributed to the observed differences in catalytic performance. Studies are underway to investigate the origin of the observed catalytic performance of heterogeneous solid Ru metal catalysts with respect to CH activation of aromatic hydrocarbons under mild oxidation conditions for further catalyst development. These studies are important given the structure–activity relationship of Ru metal catalyst phases, RuO, RuO2 and metallic Ru in hydrogenation and oxidation reactions [20]. Because the potential use of Ru or any other active metal as catalyst in solid heterogeneous catalysis will depend on the stability of its catalytic activity with prolonged exposure to the reaction mixture, or recyclability, we considered it important to investigate the structures of the Ru catalyst samples after they were used for 5 consecutive reaction cycles in the oxidation of p-cymene. Fig. 10 presents the TGA traces for the fresh and used 3%Ru/CNF catalysts. As evident in the figure, the fresh 3%Ru/CNF catalyst showed no mass loss up to approximately 450°C, and the observed weight loss at temperatures greater than 450°C can be mainly ascribed to the decomposition of carbon. By comparison, the used 3%Ru/CNF catalyst exhibited a significant mass loss that amounted to approximately 43wt.% of the sample at temperatures less than 450°C. The observed mass loss for the spent 3%Ru/CNF catalyst is ascribed to the decomposition of organic compounds adsorbed onto the catalyst surface (Fig. 10). These adsorbed polar molecules can block or structurally rearrange the active sites on catalyst surface, which may have affected its performance, as evidenced by the change in the product with its continuous re-use (Table 4). In such cases, multiple catalyst re-activations by calcination would be necessary to restore the selectivity of the catalyst. We also investigated the structural stability of 3%Ru/CNF catalyst by comparing its XRD structure before and after used in the liquid-phase oxidation of p-cymene. The results obtained are illustrated in Fig. 11 . It can be seen that the XRD structure of 3%Ru/CNF catalyst obtained before and after use was relatively the same indicating that Ru species was structurally stable under the applied liquid-phase oxidation conditions. It can therefore be inferred that the observed changes in Ru catalytic performance, especially with regard to the gradual drop of TCHP selectivity would be due to the possible adsorption of polar organics on catalyst surface. It is possible that this adsorbed surface organic can initiate the surface redox properties of the catalyst ratios, thus its selectivity toward particular products formation. This phenomenon requires further investigations to probe the extend impact of the reaction medium on molar ratios of Ru(3+)/Ru(2+)/Ru(0) and the actual role this oxidation state might be playing in the selectivity part of the catalyst using other surface species characterization techniques. We are currently, looking further into these aspects related to the actual role of Ru oxidation states on the observed catalytic performance. 4 Conclusions In this paper, the catalytic activity of Ru catalysts supported on CNFs was investigated in the liquid-phase oxidation of p-cymene. The activity of the Ru catalysts was influenced by the metal loadings. A p-cymene conversion of 55% with 33% selectivity toward TCHP and 42% toward PCHP as the predominant major products was obtained within 5h reaction time using the 3%Ru–CNF catalyst. The conversion achieved with this catalyst was better than the 3% conversion achieved in the non-catalyzed reaction The performance of the Ru/CNF catalysts using molecular oxygen as the terminal oxidant offers promising results for the possible use of Ru metal as a nano-catalyst for CH bond activation of alkyl aromatic hydrocarbons into value-added oxygenates. The results indicated that the particles size of Ru is not the primary deciding factor in the observed Ru catalytic performance toward p-cymene conversion or in the product selectivity; instead, the interplay of metal loadings, the reducibility, the different possible Ru species and the reaction conditions (i.e., the type of initiator, which is critical for reaction chain initiation) were the predominant factors. Moreover, in the absence of a radical-initiator substrate, the direct activation of the CH bond of p-cymene was slow, whereas the addition of a small amount of initiator (i.e., TBHP) significantly improved the Ru activity toward CH activation. Finally, the Ru/CNF catalyst was highly reusable without any loss of activity under the studied reaction conditions. The extended substrate scope application of Ru/CNF catalyst was successfully proven active for oxidation of other selected alkyl-substituted aromatic hydrocarbons such as cumene and styrene. These results provide the basis for further Ru catalyst development in the activation of CH bonds for the oxidation of aromatic hydrocarbons in the liquid phase. coredata.dc:description: Highly dispersed, nanosized ruthenium (Ru) particles anchored on carbon nanofibers (CNFs) with varying Ru loadings (1–7wt.%) showed effective catalytic activity in the aerobic oxidation of p-cymene using molecular oxygen. The activity of the Ru catalysts was influenced by the structural properties that resulted from the different metal loadings and by various reaction variables, such as the temperature, the amount of catalyst and the type of radical–initiator substrate. Under optimized reaction conditions, the 3%Ru/CNF catalyst exhibited excellent performance with a selectivity of 42% toward primary cymene hydroperoxide (PCHP) and 33% toward tertiary cymene hydroperoxide (TCHP) at 55% p-cymene conversion achieved within 5h at 90°C. The results demonstrated that the direct participation of the catalyst in p-cymene CH bond activation occurred via catalytic decomposition of tertiary-butyl hydroperoxide (TBHP), which was added as an initiator, into a free-radical chain initiator rather than the direct H-atom abstraction by the catalyst itself. The catalytic efficacy displayed by the Ru/CNF catalysts provides encouraging results for the activation of CH bonds of liquid-phase alkyl aromatic hydrocarbons, such as p-cymene, toward the introduction of an oxygen atom. The catalyst was reusable for five consecutive reaction cycles without appreciable loss of activity. Moreover, Ru/CNF catalyst was active for extended substrate scope application in the oxidation of other alkyl-substituted aromatics.
coredata.dc:title: Nanosized ruthenium particles decorated carbon nanofibers as active catalysts for the oxidation of p-cymene by molecular oxygen
